Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: New Urban Geographies of Domestic Work

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation improvement project will examine the shifting spatio-temporal organization of paid domestic work in the 21st century. Today, in contrast to past live-in arrangements, domestic work is much more likely to be performed by day workers who often live far away from their employers. This shift in employment arrangement represents a significant spatio-temporal reorganization of the sector as workers' daily commutes might now vary, along with their daily and weekly working hours, the number of employers for whom they work, and time spent interacting with each of them. This project will consider the significance of this reorganization by advancing theories in urban geography and the geographies of work, as well as contributing to renewed social science research interest in the micro and macro patterns of mobility. This project focuses on the domestic employment relationship, but the findings will contribute to the ongoing reformulation of concepts to better understand labor, work, and employment in the 21st century that is increasingly service-oriented, insecure, and spatially fragmented. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

This project pays close attention to the increasing spatial and temporal fragmentation of paid domestic work and its significance for workers, employers, and wider society. The project is centered on the following questions: (1) How has the spatio-temporal reorganization of paid domestic work impacted the daily lives of domestic workers and employers, particularly the household organization and management strategies of each? (2) What are the implications of these spatio-temporal changes for: a) the domestic employment relationship, and b) domestic worker organizing efforts for better working conditions? (3) How might longstanding social relations associated with the employer-employee relationship and the place of paid domestic work in society be changing in response to the reorganization of the sector? These research questions will be answered through a mixed methods approach including content analysis of domestic employment job postings and news media sources, descriptive data analysis of government data, participant observation of union activities, key informant interviews with union leaders, and in-depth interviews with domestic workers and employers. Interviews with workers will include the collection of time-diaries to develop time-space paths as a way of understanding the lived experience of navigating this increasingly fragmented work. The study will investigate these questions in Brazil but will be translatable to other contexts where domestic work is also a significant part of the economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the implications of the shifting spatio-temporal organization of paid domestic work in urban Brazil. Paid domestic work is a significant sector of employment for women--particularly working class women of color--around the world, but has long been plagued by low wages, long working hours, and limited coverage under labor laws and regulations. In Brazil, the sector has undergone major changes over the last 50 years as the dominant employment arrangements have shifted from full-time live-in workers, to full-time live-out workers, and most recently to part-time day workers. These dramatic changes in the spatio-temporal organization of the sector (that is, the living arrangements, daily commute, working hours, and number of employers), along with the historic extension of basic labor protections to full-time domestic workers only, raise a number of questions about the future of paid domestic work in Brazil. This project explored the impacts of the rise of day work arrangements on workers, employers, and unions within the sector.

Over the course of nine months of fieldwork, the project involved interviews with 42 domestic workers (24 day workers, 16 full-time workers, and 2 who work full-time in one house and as a day worker in others), 7 domestic employers, and 2 union representatives in the city of Sao Paulo. The project also drew on analysis of domestic employment job postings, popular news media sources, and federal and regional government data sets of the domestic service sector. Findings reveal that many workers enter into day work arrangements, despite the limited legal protections, because the demands of full-time arrangements often leave workers unable to fully meet their own care needs and responsibilities. In shifting to day work, workers find a number of benefits like fewer and more flexible working hours, higher wages, and a more formal or "professional" employment relationship, better enabling them to balance familial and personal care responsibilities with paid work responsibilities. However, many of these potential benefits are ultimately undermined by the lack of labor protections and benefits, as well as the instability and insecurity of day work. Because they are working informally, day workers can be fired without warning and may experience difficulty finding work in the future as they have no documentation of their previous work experience. Day workers also describe more physically demanding workdays, with employers often expecting them to complete a week's worth of cleaning in one day, and the subsequent impacts on their bodies. Finally, few day workers contribute to social security, leaving their future ability to retire in question. These findings make all the more clear the importance of extending basic labor protections to the growing number of day workers in the domestic service sector and the need for domestic workers' unions to develop new strategies for supporting these workers. 

Findings also suggest the beginnings of broader social changes in response to the reorganization of the domestic service sector. As employing a full-time domestic worker becomes less common, middle class men and children are taking on more responsibility for household chores, presenting a disruption to the traditional gender division of labor that has historically left women responsible for the bulk of household tasks. Evidence of the beginnings of a cultural shift away from expectations and acceptance of racialized servitude can also be seen, as unions engage in new campaigns that address the racial hierarchies that structure the sector and connect the struggle for domestic workers' rights to broader struggles for racial justice. 

This project contributes to a greater understanding of precarious labor and informal employment relations by offering a rich empirical study of both workers' and employers' experiences within an economically and culturally significant sector. Through presentations at conferences, as well as publications in academic journals and more publicly available sources, the project contributes to changing public attitudes regarding the value of domestic work and the importance of extending labor rights and protections to those who perform it.
